subject   : Subject: A THOROUGH AND COMPLETE SEARCH (3-1-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sat, 29 Feb 2020 18:08:31 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

Today’s Verse:
Search me, O God, and know my heart; test me and
know my thoughts. Point out anything in me that
offends You, and lead me along the path of ever-
lasting life. (Ps. 139:23-24)

Today’s Reflection:
Sometimes we think we see the whole picture, but in
reality we need someone to help us see those things
we cannot see. Oftentimes in my prayers, I ask Jesus
to reveal those things in me that are unpleasing in His
sight, those things I cannot see. It is important to me
that my thoughts and actions are pleasing in His sight.
Jesus alone can test our thoughts and shape our
heart to look like His.
Pastor Al
original_reflection_text: Sometimes we think we see the whole picture, but in reality we need someone to help us see those things we cannot see. Oftentimes in my prayers, I ask Jesus to reveal those things in me that are unpleasing in His sight, those things I cannot see. It is important to me that my thoughts and actions are pleasing in His sight. Jesus alone can test our thoughts and shape our heart to look like His.
original_verse_text: Search me, O God, and know my heart; test me and know my thoughts. Point out anything in me that offends You, and lead me along the path of ever- lasting life.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that our understanding is limited. Search us, O God, and know our hearts; test us and know our anxious thoughts (Psalm 139:23). Reveal to us those areas where we have strayed from Your ways, that we may turn from them and walk in Your truth. Help us to trust in You with all our hearts and not lean on our own understanding, that You may direct our paths (Proverbs 3:5-6). Mold us, Lord, to be pleasing in Your sight. Amen.
reflection: Sometimes we think we see the whole picture, but in reality we need someone to help us see those things we cannot see. Oftentimes in my prayers, I ask Jesus to reveal those things in me that are unpleasing in His sight, those things I cannot see. It is important to me that my thoughts and actions are pleasing in His sight. Jesus alone can test our thoughts and shape our heart to look like His.
subject: A Thorough and Complete Search
verse_text: Search me, O God, and know my heart; test me and know my thoughts. Point out anything in me that offends You, and lead me along the path of ever- lasting life.

subject   : Subject: TIME TO REJOICE (3-2-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sun, 1 Mar 2020 18:23:57 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*This is the day that the Lord has made. Let us *

*rejoice **and be glad in it! *(Ps. 118:24)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Wouldn’t be great if we could feel enthusiastic every

day? I think we’ve all had days that we did not feel

like rejoicing. Our mood was down, our situation was

out of hand, and our sorrow or guilt was overwhelming.

When you don’t feel like rejoicing. Tell God how you

truly feel. You will find that God will give you some-

thing to rejoice about*. God has given you* *this day to *

*live and serve Him—be glad!*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Wouldn’t be great if we could feel enthusiastic every
day?
I think we’ve all had days that we did not feel
like rejoicing. Our mood was down, our situation was
out of hand, and our sorrow or guilt was overwhelming.
When you don’t feel like rejoicing. Tell God how you
truly feel. You will find that God will give you some thing to rejoice about. God has given you this day to live and serve Him-be glad!
original_verse_text: This is the day that the Lord has made. Let us  rejoice and be glad in it!
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts that may not always feel joyful or enthusiastic. In the midst of our struggles and sorrows, help us to remember that this is the day You have made, and we can rejoice and be glad in it (Psalm 118:24). Give us the strength to rejoice in You always, as Your Word instructs (Philippians 4:4). When our circumstances weigh us down, lift our spirits and fill us with Your peace and joy. We trust in Your goodness and faithfulness, Lord. Amen.
reflection: Wouldn't it be great if we could feel enthusiastic every day? I think we've all had days that we did not feel like rejoicing. Our mood was down, our situation was out of hand, and our sorrow or guilt was overwhelming. When you don't feel like rejoicing, tell God how you truly feel. You will find that God will give you something to rejoice about. God has given you this day to live and serve Him—be glad!
subject: Time to Rejoice
verse_text: This is the day that the Lord has made. Let us  rejoice and be glad in it!

subject   : Subject: PURE UNQUESTIONABLE HUMILITY (3-3-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*He must increase, but I must decrease. *(Jn. 3:30)



*Today’s Reflection:*

John’s willingness to decrease *in* importance shows unusual humility.
Pastor, (yes pastors) and other Christian leaders can be tempted to focus
more on the success of their ministries than on Christ. Beware of those who
put more emphasis on on their own achievements than on God’s Kingdom. If
you find

that you have a problem with pride, pray this prayer.

*Jesus, release me from all personal ambitions and selfish **motives.*

* Pastor Al *
original_reflection_text:
John’s willingness to decrease in importance shows unusual humility.
Pastor, (yes pastors) and other Christian leaders can be tempted to focus more on the success of their ministries than on Christ. Beware of those who put more emphasis on on their own achievements than on God’s Kingdom. If you find that you have a problem with pride, pray this prayer. Jesus, release me from all personal ambitions and selfish motives.
original_verse_text: He must increase, but I must decrease.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging that You alone are worthy of all glory and praise. Help us to follow the example of John the Baptist, who willingly decreased so that Christ might increase. May we never be tempted to seek our own success or achievements above the advancement of Your kingdom. Lord, release us from all personal ambitions and selfish motives, that we may serve You with pure hearts and selfless love. In Your Son's name we pray, Amen.
reflection: John's willingness to decrease in importance shows unusual humility. Pastor (yes, pastors) and other Christian leaders can be tempted to focus more on the success of their ministries than on Christ. Beware of those who put more emphasis on their own achievements than on God's Kingdom. If you find that you have a problem with pride, pray this prayer: “Jesus, release me from all personal ambitions and selfish motives.”
subject: Pure Unquestionable Humility
verse_text: He must increase, but I must decrease.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Ask, and it shall be given to you; seek, and you shall*

*find; knock, and it shall be opened to you. *(Mat. 7:7)



*Today’s Reflection:*

I believe that miracles happen every day, and Jesus knows what I need
before I make my requests, BUT

I’m still required to pray. Have you ever wondered

why? It is to open ourselves up to a personal relationship with the Savior.
As I make bold requests from the Lord,

I boldly receive His abundance and provisions for family, friends, and
myself. *So why don't we all c**ome boldly to **the throne of grace each
morning?*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
I believe that miracles happen every day, and Jesus knows what I need before I make my requests, BUT I’m still required to pray.
Have you ever wondered why? It is to open ourselves up to a personal relationship with the Savior. As I make bold requests from the Lord, I boldly receive His abundance and provisions for family, friends, and myself. So why don't we all come boldly to the throne of grace each morning?
original_verse_text:
Ask, and it shall be given to you; seek, and you shall find;
knock, and it shall be opened to you.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, knowing that You hear our prayers and long to pour out Your blessings upon us. As we approach Your throne of grace, may we do so with confidence, trusting in Your perfect timing and Your abundant provision. Lord, help us to boldly make our requests known, for You know our needs even before we ask. May our prayers draw us closer to You, that we may experience the fullness of Your love and grace. Amen.
reflection: I believe that miracles happen every day, and Jesus knows what I need before I make my requests, but I'm still required to pray. Have you ever wondered why? It is to open ourselves up to a personal relationship with the Savior. As I make bold requests from the Lord, I boldly receive His abundance and provisions for family, friends, and myself. So why don't we all come boldly to the throne of grace each morning?
subject: Amazing Prayer!
verse_text:
Ask, and it shall be given to you; seek, and you shall find;
knock, and it shall be opened to you.

*Today’s Verse:*

*You will show me the way of life, granting me the joy **of Your presence
and the pleasures of living with You **forever. *(Ps. 16:11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The joys and benefits of a life lived in companion-

ship with God are beyond human comprehension. And the greatest thing of all
is, these benefits are now and forever. I think that to often we read
verses and don’t stop and really think about what the verse has really
revealed. So let’s give this some time to soak in. What are the benefits? I
believe He is offering a structure, open to

heaven, framing our pathway home in a way that adds clarity, beauty and a
hint of greatness. *But *

He still allows room for natural growth already in progress. It’s all about
the on-the-way-there moments. *Is Jesus **smiling down on you today and
saying, Thanks For **Following Me**!*

*Pastor Al*

Help us to savor the beauty and clarity You provide along the journey, ever mindful of Your smile of approval. May we joyfully follow in the footsteps of our Savior, Jesus Christ. Amen.

subject   : Subject: LIVING IN READINESS (3-6-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*Be dressed for service. . . . Be like people waiting for *

*t**he master to come home. *(Lk. 12:35—36)



*Today’s Reflection:*

From the context of this passage, it’s obvious “dressed”

doesn’t mean wearing an apron at all times *or* dressing

in what used to be called our “Sunday best” in case Jesus

returns before our next breath. But it seems clear He

meant it to include anytime He calls on us, not just when

He calls us home. *Let us spend time today*

*considering how we can be royal-ready for what**ever *

*He requires.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: From the context of this passage, it’s obvious “dressed” doesn’t mean wearing an apron at all times or dressing in what used to be called our “Sunday best” in case Jesus returns before our next breath. But it seems clear He meant it to include anytime He calls on us, not just when He calls us home. Let us spend time today considering how we can be royal-ready for whatever He requires.
original_verse_text: Be dressed ready for service and keep your lamps burning, like servants waiting for their master to return from a wedding banquet.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, mindful of Your imminent return. Help us to be ever-vigilant, with our lamps lit and our hearts prepared to serve You at a moment's notice. May we be found faithful, dressed and ready to do Your will, whether You call us to our eternal home or to a task in this world. Keep us alert and obedient, that we may be found worthy when You appear. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: From the context of this passage, it's obvious “dressed” doesn't mean wearing an apron at all times or dressing in what used to be called our “Sunday best” in case Jesus returns before our next breath. But it seems clear He meant it to include any time He calls on us, not just when He calls us home. Let us spend time today considering how we can be royal-ready for whatever He requires.
subject: Living in Readiness
verse_text: Be dressed ready for service and keep your lamps burning, like servants waiting for their master to return from a wedding banquet.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee **and the other a
tax collector. The Pharisee stood by **himself and prayed, “God I thank You
that I am not **like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or **even
like this tax-collector. *(Lk. 18:10-11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Like the pharisee, we can be influenced by mixed

emotions in our daily lives: pride, fear, winning

the praise of people, or a desire to control. We can often do the
*right *things
for the *wrong *reasons. Jesus challenges us to go deeper. To make choices
motivated by trust and love. At times, He will encourage us to step forward
boldly. Other times He will call us to step back and rest. *Both actions
require trust and an honest evaluation of our-*

*selves.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Like the pharisee, we can be influenced by mixed
emotions in our daily lives: pride, fear, winning the praise of people, or a desire to control. We can often do the right things for the wrong reasons. Jesus challenges us to go deeper. To make choices motivated by trust and love. At times, He will encourage us to step forward boldly. Other times He will call us to step back and rest. Both actions require trust and an honest evaluation of our selves.
original_verse_text: Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed, “God I thank You that I am not like other people-robbers, evildoers, adulterers-or even like this tax-collector.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging the tendency within us to be influenced by pride, fear, and a desire for the praise of others. Help us to go deeper, to make choices motivated by trust and love rather than selfish ambition. When You call us to step forward boldly, grant us the courage to do so. And when You call us to step back and rest, give us the faith to obey. May our actions and attitudes be pleasing in Your sight, not for our own glory, but for Yours alone. Amen.
reflection: Like the Pharisee, we can be influenced by mixed emotions in our daily lives: pride, fear, winning the praise of people, or a desire to control. We can often do the right things for the wrong reasons. Jesus challenges us to go deeper. To make choices motivated by trust and love. At times, He will encourage us to step forward boldly. Other times, He will call us to step back and rest. Both actions require trust and an honest evaluation of ourselves.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus asked Simon Peter, “. . . Do you love me *

*More than these?” *(Jn. 21:15)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus’s faithful, unchanging nature is a rock-sold

truth we can count on. When Jesus invites us by

saying, “follow me,” He is also saying, “you can

count on Me. The road may be treacherous, but

I’ll keep you safe. I’ll light the way for you, and

you can rely on my strength. I don’t mind carrying

you. And I don’t get distracted, or consumed by

other issues, or relax my grip on you.”

*Remember Jesus has promised to never leave you **or forsake you—What are
your vows to Him?*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus’s faithful, unchanging nature is a rock-sold
truth we can count on. When Jesus invites us by
saying, “follow me,” He is also saying, “you can
count on Me. The road may be treacherous, but
I’ll keep you safe. I’ll light the way for you, and
you can rely on my strength. I don’t mind carrying
you.
And I don’t get distracted, or consumed by
other issues, or relax my grip on you.”
Remember Jesus has promised to never leave you or forsake you-What are your vows to Him?
original_verse_text: Jesus asked Simon Peter, "Do you love me  More than these?"
prayer: Heavenly Father, we are grateful for the steadfast love and unwavering presence of Your Son, our Lord Jesus Christ. As He calls us to follow Him, we find comfort in the assurance that You will never leave us nor forsake us. Help us to respond with faithful obedience, trusting in Your strength to guide us through the treacherous paths of life. May our lives be a testament to Your unfailing love and our commitment to walk in Your ways. Amen.
reflection: Jesus's faithful, unchanging nature is a rock-solid truth we can count on. When Jesus invites us by saying, “Follow me,” He is also saying, “You can count on Me. The road may be treacherous, but I'll keep you safe. I'll light the way for you, and you can rely on my strength. I don't mind carrying you. And I don't get distracted or consumed by other issues, or relax my grip on you.” Remember, Jesus has promised to never leave you or forsake you. What are your vows to Him?
subject: Never Fear
verse_text: Jesus asked Simon Peter, “Do you love me  More than these?”

*Today’s Verse:*

*Teachers of the religious law asked . . . “Why does*

*He eat with tax collectors and sinners?” When *

*Jesus heard this, He told them, “Those who are*

*well don’t need a doctor, but the sick do need one.*

(Mk. 2:16-17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus spent time with whoever needed or wanted

to hear the message—poor, rich, bad, and good.

We too, must befriend those who need Christ,

even if they do not seem to be ideal companions.

Are there people you are neglecting because of

their reputation? They may be the ones who most

need to hear and see the message of Christ’s love

in and from you. *Are you trying the “get a grip” instead **of resting* *in
the grip of Jesus.*

*Pastor Al*

Help us to follow the example of Your Son, Jesus, who welcomed and ministered to those who were often shunned by society. Give us the courage and compassion to befriend those who may not seem like ideal companions, for they may be the ones who need to experience Your transformative love the most. Strengthen our faith, that we may rest securely in Your grip, rather than trying to “get a grip” on our own. In Your Son's name, we pray. Amen.

subject   : Subject: GIVING HIM HUMBLE THANKS (3-11-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*Sing and make music from your hear to the Lord*

*always **giving thanks to God the Father for every-*

*thing, in the **name of our Lord Jesus Christ.*

(Eph. 5:19-20)


*Today’s Reflection:*

When you feel down, you may find it difficult to

give thanks. *But *take heart—in all things God works

for our good if we love him and are called by Him

(Ro. 8:28). Thank God not for your problems, but

for the strength He is building in you through the

difficult experiences in your life. *You can be **sure *

*that **God’s perfect love will see your through.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: When you feel down, you may find it difficult to give thanks. But take heart-in all things God works for our good if we love him and are called by Him (Romans 8:28). Thank God not for your problems, but for the strength He is building in you through the difficult experiences in your life. You can be sure that God’s perfect love will see your through.
original_verse_text: Sing and make music from your hear to the Lord always giving thanks to God the Father for every- thing, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that in all things, You work for our good (Romans 8:28). Even in the midst of our struggles and challenges, we choose to give thanks, for You are building strength and character within us through these experiences. May our hearts be filled with the richness of Your Word, as we sing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, giving thanks to You always (Ephesians 5:19-20; Colossians 3:16). We trust in Your perfect love to guide and sustain us, now and forevermore. Amen.
reflection: When you feel down, you may find it difficult to give thanks. But take heart—in all things God works for our good if we love him and are called by him (Romans 8:28). Thank God not for your problems, but for the strength he is building in you through the difficult experiences in your life. You can be sure that God's perfect love will see you through.
subject: Giving Him Humble Thanks
verse_text: Sing and make music from your hear to the Lord always giving thanks to God the Father for every- thing, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

*Today’s Verse: *

*My sheep know my voice; I know them and they follow **me. I give them
eternal life, and they shall never perish; **no one will snatch them out of
my hand. *(Jn. 10:27, 28)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus has promised an eternal home to those who become one with Him. A
place where we can live within His eternal glory forever. A place where

no one can harm us. A place where no one can steal us from the safety of
His hand. We have been

adopted into a kingdom beyond anything we have

ever dreamed possible, where hope and power and love reign. *And we need
never go hungry or fear again.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus has promised an eternal home to those who become one with Him. A place where we can live within His eternal glory forever. A place where no one can harm us. A place where no one can steal us from the safety of His hand. We have been adopted into a kingdom beyond anything we have
ever dreamed possible, where hope and power and love reign. And we need never go hungry or fear again.
original_verse_text:
My sheep know my voice; I know them and they follow me.
I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; no one will snatch them out of my hand.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we praise You for the eternal hope found in Your Son, Jesus Christ. You have promised that those who follow Him will dwell in Your presence, where there is no more hunger, thirst, or pain. Keep us securely in the palm of Your hand, that we may never be snatched away from the safety of Your love. May we rest in the assurance of Your eternal glory, where You will guide us to springs of living water. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Jesus has promised an eternal home to those who become one with Him. A place where we can live within His eternal glory forever. A place where no one can harm us. A place where no one can steal us from the safety of His hand. We have been adopted into a kingdom beyond anything we have ever dreamed possible, where hope and power and love reign. And we need never go hungry or fear again.
subject: Being One with Jesus

My sheep know my voice; I know them and they follow me.
I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; no one will snatch them out of my hand.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The tongue is a flame of fire. It is full of wickedness*

*that can ruin your whole life. It can turn the entire*

*course of your whole life into a blazing flame of*

*destruction, for it is set on fire by hell itself.*

(Jm. 3:6)



*Today’s Reflection:*

James says, the source of the wicked tongue comes from hell itself. *Satan
*uses the tongue to divide people and pit themselves against one another.
Idle and hateful words are damaging because they spread destruction
quickly, and no one can stop the results once they are spoken. We dare not
be careless with what we say, thinking we can apologize latter, because
even if we do, the scares remain. *Before **we speak* *remember words are
like fire—you **can neither* *control or reverse the damage they **can do.*

* Pastor Al*

Before we speak remember words are like fire-you can neither control or reverse the damage they can do.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, recognizing the power of the tongue and the destruction it can bring. Help us to be mindful of our words, for they have the ability to build up or tear down. May we not be careless, speaking words that divide and spread discord, for we know they originate from the evil one. Instead, grant us the wisdom to speak life, to encourage one another, and to bring glory to Your name. May our tongues be instruments of Your peace, that we may honor You in all we say. Amen.

subject   : Subject: THE DIVIDING LINE (3-14-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

date      : Fri, 13 Mar 2020 17:53:04 -0500
===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*I know your deeds, that they are neither cold nor hot. I **wish you were
one or the other! So, because you are **lukewarm—neither hot nor cold—I am
about to spit you **out of my mouth. *(Rev. 3:15-16)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Today we see lines everywhere. They are in parking lots, at intersections,
baseball diamonds, basketball courts, and football fields. Lines can

be very important. They help us know where we stand. Jesus too, drew a line
when He called those from the multitude to follow Him. Jesus’ words make a
very perfect line: either you are for Christ or you are against Him. That
same line exists today. We must decide on which side of the line

we will stand. There is no middle ground with the Lord. If fact, for those who
try, it makes Him sick to His stomach. “He will spit them out.”

*A lot of people want to serve God, BUT only*

*on an advisory capacity. *
* Pastor Al*

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that there is no middle ground when it comes to following You. Help us to stand firmly on the side of Christ, not wavering or trying to serve You on our own terms. Give us the courage to make a clear decision to be for You, not against You. May we not be lukewarm, but fervent in our devotion, for You desire wholehearted commitment. We surrender ourselves to You, Lord, and pray that You would empower us to live out our faith with unwavering resolve. Amen.

know His **voice. *Jn. 10:3—4)

23 as a prayer to Jesus. Verses one and two might sound like this: ”

peaceful streams.*

* Pastor Al*

subject   : Subject: GENEROSITY AND DILIGENCE (3-16-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verse:*

*Give generously, for your gifts will return to you latter. **Divide your
gifts among many, for you do not know **what risks might lie ahead. *

(Eccl. 11:1-2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

In these verses Solomon summarizes that life involves both risk and
opportunity. Because life has no guarantees, we must be prepared. “Give
generously,” because life has opportunities and

we must seize them. Solomon does not support

a stingy, despairing attitude. Just because life is

uncertain does not mean we should do nothing.

We need a spirit of trust and adventure, facing

life’ risk and opportunities with God-directed enthusiasm and faith. *Waiting
for perfect conditions will mean inactivity.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
In these verses Solomon summarizes that life involves both risk and opportunity. Because life has no guarantees, we must be prepared. “Give generously,” because life has opportunities and we must seize them. Solomon does not support a stingy, despairing attitude. Just because life is
uncertain does not mean we should do nothing. We need a spirit of trust and adventure, facing life’ risk and opportunities with God-directed enthusiasm and faith. Waiting for perfect conditions will mean inactivity.
original_verse_text: Give generously, for your gifts will return to you latter. Divide your gifts among many, for you do not know what risks might lie ahead.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with open hearts, seeking to walk in the wisdom You have graciously provided. Help us to have a spirit of trust and adventure, facing the risks and opportunities of life with enthusiasm and faith in You. May we give generously, not holding back, for You have promised to bless us abundantly. Guide us, Lord, to seize the opportunities You set before us, even when the conditions are not perfect. We surrender our lives to You, trusting in Your perfect plan. Amen.
reflection: In these verses, Solomon summarizes that life involves both risk and opportunity. Because life has no guarantees, we must be prepared. “Give generously,” because life has opportunities and we must seize them. Solomon does not support a stingy, despairing attitude. Just because life is uncertain does not mean we should do nothing. We need a spirit of trust and adventure, facing life's risks and opportunities with God-directed enthusiasm and faith. Waiting for perfect conditions will mean inactivity.
subject: Generosity and Diligence
verse_text: Give generously, for your gifts will return to you latter. Divide your gifts among many, for you do not know what risks might lie ahead.

*Today’s Verses:*

*Be still, and know that I am God. *(Ps. 46:10)

*Be holy because I am holy. *(Lev. 11:46)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The most important use of our day is to practice being like Jesus. *Even*
when we have-to-deal with a difficult person *OR *when we receive bad news.
Every-day we can expect to encounter plenty of opportunities to choose
between behaving like Christ would, and acting on the basis of our natural
instincts. In those moments, what we do *will* reflect who we are
becoming. *AND
that is much more important **than crossing off every item on the longest
to-do list.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
The most important use of our day is to practice being like Jesus.
Even when we have-to-deal with a difficult person OR when we receive bad news. Every-day we can expect to encounter plenty of opportunities to choose between behaving like Christ would, and acting on the basis of our natural instincts. In those moments, what we do will reflect who we are becoming. AND that is much more important than crossing off every item on the longest to-do list.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, seeking to be conformed to the image of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help us to practice holiness and righteousness, even in the face of life's challenges and difficulties. Grant us the wisdom and strength to respond with love, patience, and grace, just as our Lord did. May our actions and attitudes reflect the transformation You are working in our hearts, that we may be perfect, as our Heavenly Father is perfect. In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord has made everything for His own purpose. *(Pro. 14:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus’s purpose on earth was to preach the gospel,

heal the sick and brokenhearted, and to set the

captives free. He had an appointed time to work

on earth before He fulfilled His other purpose,

which was dying to save us. *When He left*, Jesus

purposed us with continuing the work He started

on earth with each of us working *as a sole example*

bring hope, beauty, and truth to the world. Like

the bees that spread pollen, we are meant to spread

the love of Jesus. When we seek Jesus, *He helps*

*us to fulfill our purpose in our jobs, churches,*

*families, and communities.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus’s purpose on earth was to preach the gospel,
heal the sick and brokenhearted, and to set the
captives free. He had an appointed time to work
on earth before He fulfilled His other purpose,
which was dying to save us. When He left, Jesus
purposed us with continuing the work He started
on earth with each of us working as a sole example
bring hope, beauty, and truth to the world. Like
the bees that spread pollen, we are meant to spread
the love of Jesus. When we seek Jesus, He helps us to fulfill our purpose in our jobs, churches, families, and communities.
original_verse_text: The Lord has made everything for His own purpose.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the example of Jesus, who came to preach the good news, heal the brokenhearted, and set the captives free. Lord, help us to follow in His footsteps, seeking to spread the love and truth of Your gospel in our workplaces, churches, families, and communities. May we be like the bees, diligently working to bring hope and beauty to the world around us. Guide us by Your Spirit to fulfill the purpose You have for each of us. Amen.
reflection: Jesus’s purpose on earth was to preach the gospel, heal the sick and brokenhearted, and to set the captives free. He had an appointed time to work on earth before He fulfilled His other purpose, which was dying to save us. When He left, Jesus purposed us with continuing the work He started on earth with each of us working as a sole example bring hope, beauty, and truth to the world. Like the bees that spread pollen, we are meant to spread the love of Jesus. When we seek Jesus, He helps us to fulfill our purpose in our jobs, churches, families, and communities.
subject: Having a Purpose
verse_text: The Lord has made everything for His own purpose.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The rich think of their wealth as an impregnable *

*defense, they imagine it is a high wall of safety.*

(Ps. 18:11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

In imagining that their wealth is their strongest

defense, rich people are sadly mistaken. Money

cannot provide safety—there are to many ways

for it to lose its power. The Government may

cease to back it; thieves may steal it; inflation

may rob it of its value. But God never loses His

power. He is always dependable. Where do you

look for your security and safety—*in uncertain*

*wealth OR God who is always faithful?*

* Pastor Sather *


(sorry for the delay I was having computer problems)

*Today’s Verse:*

*Your prayers and your compassionate gifts to*

*the poor have not gone unnoticed by God!*

(Acts 10:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God saw Cornelius’s sincere faith. His prayers

and his generous giving had not gone unnoticed

by God. God answers the sincere prayers of those

who seek Him by sending the right person or the

right information at the right time. Jesus’s life

was consumed with prayer and compassionate

acts. *Can the same be said about yours?*

*[To many people offer God prayer with claw marks*

*all over them!**] *

*Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Pray without ceasing. *(I Thess. 5:17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

We are living in a difficult time, when it is very important that we truly
pray without ceasing. Just how are we to do this? Well

Paul gives this advise; he says: “be joyful” and “pray without ceasing” he
also says “no matter what happens, always be thankful,” for this is God’s
will. It goes

without saying we cannot spend all our time on our knees, but it is
possible, to have a prayerful attitude, at all times.

This attitude is built upon acknowledging our dependence, on God realizing
His presence within us, and determining to

obey Him fully. Then we will find it natural to pray frequently,
spontaneously, short prayers.* Would you **enlist and become a faithful
prayer warrior?*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Then Jesus prayed this prayer: “O Father, Lord of heaven **and earth,
thank for hiding the truth from those who think **themselves so **wise and
clever, and for revealing it to the **childlike. *(Mt. 11:25)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus mentions two kinds of people; “the wise and cleaver” arrogant in
their own knowledge—and the “childlike”—

humbly open to receive the truth of God’s Word. Are you wise in your own
eyes, or do you seek the truth in childlike faith,

realizing that only God holds all the answers. *In the O. T. to “know”
means more than knowledge. It **means to have an intimate relationship.*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verses:*

*One of the Pharisees in order to trap Jesus asked, **“Teacher, which is
the most important commandment **in the law of Moses?” Jesus replied, “You
must **love *

*the Lord your God with all your heart, with **all your soul, and with all
your mind. *(Mt. 22:36-38)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The Pharisee who asked this question was attempting to stump Jesus. But
Jesus reminded the Pharisee, and He reminds

us, that when we feel overwhelmed by

commands and rules, we can come back

to the core truth. Our God wants to be in

a relationship with us. Because of Jesus,

that relationship is restored. We never

go wrong when we poor our hearts, souls, and minds into love for our
Lord. *Jesus
said, “This is **the greatest command.”*

*Pastor Sather*

Help us to pour out our love for You, not out of duty, but from a place of deep devotion and adoration. May our hearts, souls, and minds be fully surrendered to You, the One who has restored our relationship through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus. In Your presence, we find true peace and purpose. We worship You, the Lord our God. Amen.

*Today's Verses:*

*“You shall have no other gods before Me. You shall not make **for yourself
a carved image.” *(Exodus 20:3-4b)


*Today's Reflection:*

Read these two verses once again. Don't you think that we should be
concerned?

GOD DEALING* WITH TODAY’S IDOL WORSHIP*

In three short months just like God did with the plagues In Egypt, God has
taken away everything we worship. We are

known for the worship of athletes, so I will

Shut down your stadiums. We worship our musicians, I will shut down your
Civic Centers. We worship actors, I will shut down the theaters. We worship
money, I

will shut down the economy and crush the stock market. You don’t want to go
to church and worship me, I will make it so

you can’t go to church. If my people

called by my name will humble them-

selves and pray and keep the faith, and turn from their wicked ways, then I
will hear them from heaven and forgive their

sins and heal their land. Maybe we don’t need a vaccine*!* maybe instead we
should take the time to avoid the distractions of the world *and have a
personal revival where we focus **on the only thing in the world that
really matters, Jesus **Christ. ** Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Happy are those servants whom the master finds **waiting up when he
arrives. . . . he will dress him**self to serve, seat them at the table as
honored **guests, and wait on them. *(Lk. 12:37)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus is asking us to be dressed and ready, like a well-trained and beloved
servant anticipating our Master’s arrival. But He added more to the story from
Luke 12. He said that the servants who are “Waiting up” when He arrives
home, no matter

the hour, are happy and blessed. Not tired. Not exhausted. Not impatient.
Happy. Then if you notice the tables are turned. The master dresses himself
to *serve,* seats us in a place of honor, and waits on us. I can’t imagine
a more humbling

experience than having Jesus serve me in that way. *Won’t that be something
to write home **about?*

* Pastor Sather*

Not impatient. Happy. Then if you notice the tables are turned. The master dresses himself to serve, seats us in a place of honor, and waits on us. I can’t imagine a more humbling

May we be humbled by the thought of You, the King of kings, dressing Yourself to serve us. Lord, may we faithfully steward the gifts and responsibilities You have entrusted to us, that we may one day hear the words, “Well done, good and faithful servant.” Amen.

subject   : Subject: TRUSTING IN JESUS PAYS OFF (4:1-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Tue, 31 Mar 2020 17:51:02 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verses:*

At dawn Jesus called out “Friends, have you caught any fish?” “No,” they
replied. “Throw out your net on the right-hand side of the boat, and you’ll
get plenty of fish!” So they did, and they couldn’t draw in the net because
there were so many fish in it.


*Today’s Reflection:*

Give this some thought: they had been casting out their nets all night
long. They were tired and ready to go home eat some breakfast and go to
bed. If you read verse four, it says they didn’t even recognize who was on
the beach. I can hear one

of them saying to the rest, why not we have nothing to lose. Well we know
what happened, they caught so many fish they

could not get them into the boat. I think that once in-a-while we need to
be reminded to trust Jesus. I also think that

if we did we’d be much better off. *So let us remember to **ask Jesus to
teach us to trust that He will provide for us.*

* Pastor Sather*

We ask that You would strengthen our faith, that we may walk boldly in the light of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.
